boat.full_description:
First registered 28 October, 1881 as a Class 2 pilchard boat, she was later re-registered as a Class 1 mackerel driver. Her fishing no. SS 634 is said to have been chosen as it corresponds to the hymn no. for 'Will your anchor hold' in the Methodist hymnbook.

Barnabas is a dipping lugger and fished from St Ives until 1954 when she was sold as a yacht. Her working year began in March, fishing for mackerel, sometimes as far west as the Isles of Scilly. In midsummer she switched to herring in the Irish Sea, often fishing off Howth, near Dublin. Her crew of five men and a boy all ate and slept in the cramped foc’sle. The drift nets were shot at night.
boat.name: Barnabas

ownerships.note: Built for her first owner, Barnabas Thomas, in 1881.
ownerships.text: Built for her first owner, Barnabas Thomas, in

ownerships.note: In the 1970s, she was given to the National Maritime Trust and restored to her original state, thanks to the generosity of Peter Cadbury whose family had her in the 1950s.

boat.short_description: 'Barnabas' is the only survivor from St Ives of the 1,000-strong fleet of lug rigged seine and drift net fishing boats registered at Cornish ports at the turn of the 19th century. Restored to sailing condition, she is owned by the Cornish Maritime Trust and is undertaking a round Britain passage in 2015.
